question_text: A 45-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-month history of a burning sensation in the anterior chest, usually after meals, that has been unresponsive to twice-daily proton pump inhibitor therapy.Upper endoscopy results are shown.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is erosive esophagitis (Option C). Erosive esophagitis is characterized by the presence of superficial esophageal erosions, which may be associated with minor bleeding. Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is caused by reflux of gastric contents into the esophagus, and long-standing GERD can lead to complications, including erosive esophagitis, peptic stricture, Barrett esophagus, and esophageal adenocarcinoma.
